element.name: Herbert's Drey by Kili or bust, Multi-cache (1/1)

center.font: Visit The Geocaching Ireland discussion forum HERE

element.long-description:
The cache is a smallish green box tucked away neatly by nature. You will need to ensure that you are not muggled while retrieving this one and please BE DELICATE while doings so as things have been damaged in the past.
The coordinates above will take you into a part of Herbert Park in Ballsbridge, Dublin 4 for answer 1.
Ans 1. A shooting rotarian is evident resting nearby. What was his age at death.
Answer 1 = ??
Final coordinates: N53 19.476 + Ans.1 ?? W006 14.029
HERBERT PARK
There was an old millrace on the river Dodder, the remains of which may still be seen near the back gate from the park to the Dodder pathway.
At Herbert Park Lane there was a famous mill in the 17th century. Calico was printed and processed there and the whole area was used as a “bleaching green” where the cloth was laid out on the grass.
When Johnston Mooney and O’Brien took it over they converted it into a “landmark” bakery in Dublin 4. which operated here for 150 years.
Herbert Park is named after the Right Honourable Sidney Herbert 1810-1861 Lord Herbert of Lea. He was the father of the Earl of Pembroke who offered the land to the Pembroke Urban District Council for public use in 1903.
The Great Exhibition of 1907 took place here. It included national exhibits and fine arts and industrial displays from many countries.
It took 5 years to construct the massive stands and entertainments. The whole “British Empire” was represented and it included an “Indian village” and a spectacular Canadian water slide into the pond which forms part of today’s park.
After the exhibition the park was officially opened on 19th August 1911 and in 1932 it was taken over by Dublin Corporation.
The facilities in the park include 18 tennis courts, 3 football pitches, a bowling green and a children’s playing area.
In 1997 during the development of the bakery site, a major pedestrian mall was created through to Ballsbridge.
The area around this park includes some of the most expensive real estate in Ireland and rivals values in many other parts of Europe.

ul.li:
2010-06-06T19:00:00Z : Found it by Titanium Bill
did this from redding ca, thanks for the hide.
Titanium Bill

2010-04-12T19:00:00Z : Found it by 3-guineas
Likely Whiteandblack has longer arms then I have. He went fishing and found it. TFTC in this nice park.

2010-04-12T19:00:00Z : Found it by whiteandblack
I have the impression that this cache had a little 'accident' and hence was extremely difficult to find. We placed it back in the intended way (i suppose) Thanks for the cache (and the surprising hiding place)

2010-02-27T20:00:00Z : Found it by Toffee Man
This cache is in a nice hiding place. I actually felt around the place on a previous visit but an extra stretch today brought the required result. TFTC Toffee Man #222

2010-02-27T20:00:00Z : Found it by Blue Jay 59
Found this one this afternoon with guess who? Toffee Man [:)] Found the resting rotarian quickly and then went fishing, well Toffee Man did, I couldn't reach....
TFTC - lovely park, I had never been in here, though passed many times. Blue Jay 59 #220

2007-10-04T07:00:00Z : Write note by Kersti.com
Just dropping in a travel bug...

2007-08-19T07:00:00Z : Found it by Kersti.com
Found with Cam and Toadster. Found the first clue in a few seconds, nice easy one.
Thanks to some dubious maths (never trust the maths of the stranger you pick up caching...) we spent a good while searching the exact wrong spot and getting frustrated, especially after our earlier DNF. A re-think and recalculation sent us straight to the cache.
Brushed off the hitch-hikers on the cache - it's in great condition.
T - lighter L - rolly stamp
